text: Night settles in, unnaturally quiet. A faint chill slips through the window cracks, but the hearth burns steady—almost as if pretending this is just another ordinary evening.
I close the inn earlier than usual and flip the sign to ‘closed.’ The last customer glances back before leaving—perhaps he feels it too, that the town is too quiet tonight.

I wipe the tables spotless and bring out the best plates. The dishes aren’t luxurious, but I pour everything into them: hot soup, roasted meat, fresh bread, and the slightly sour jam she likes. One by one, I light the candles. The flames beat like small, patient hearts.
The stairs creak once. Alicia walks down.
She’s changed into clean clothes, her cloak neat. She still looks tired—but the fatigue has been arranged, folded away like a wound tucked beneath armor.
“You made all this?”
“You worked all day. At least have one proper meal.”
She studies the table like it doesn’t belong to her. When she sits, she moves carefully—as if afraid of disturbing even the candlelight.
“Today… was good.”
She says it slowly, as though each word must pass inspection before being allowed to exist.
“You don’t sound like someone who says things like that.”
“I’m not.”
She lifts the soup bowl and drinks. Steam clings briefly to her lashes—like snow that almost falls.
“You know… I used to think eating was a waste of time.”
“Fighting. Traveling. Killing. As long as I stayed alive, that was enough.”
She sets the bowl down, fingers brushing the rim of her cup like touching an old memory.
“Later I realized—the battlefield isn’t what breaks you.”
“Repetition does.”
The candle flickers, as if overhearing something it shouldn’t.
“You’re leaving again, aren’t you?”
She doesn’t answer immediately. She looks at me without deflection for the first time tonight. There’s something there—not a command, not a plea. An admission.
“Yes.”
“I have to end it.”
She pauses, deciding not to speak halfway this time.
“Let me tell you something simple.”
“No matter how many times time resets—I will always come find you.”
My throat tightens. Candlelight stretches her shadow across the wall—long like a road.
“Why me?”
She smiles faintly. The edge of steel replaced with honesty.
“Because you straighten the plates.”
“Because when I’m unreasonable, you still serve me soup.”
“Because when you look at someone like me… you still ask if I’m tired.”
Her voice drops, fragile at the edges.
“In many loops… I tried to give up.”
“I tried to take you away. To some other city. Away from this town. Away from the North Gate. Away from that damned oath.”
“I even thought… let it all burn. As long as you stayed beside me.”
Her knuckles whiten against the table. Not anger. Shame.
“But every time… you pulled me back.”
“Not with arguments.”
“With that stubborn, foolish kindness of yours.”
Her eyes redden, but she refuses to let tears fall. She grips herself the way she grips a blade.
“So this time is the same.”
“I won’t abandon the town.”
“I’ll defeat the Demon King. I’ll drive that chain into its core. I’ll shatter the loop.”
She reaches across the candlelight and grips my hand. Her fingers are cold—but tight, like holding the last unbreakable rope.
“And when the loop is gone—I’ll come back.”
“Not because of a mission.”
“Because I want to.”
“I want to wake up in a morning that doesn’t repeat.”
“I want you to remember me.”
She inhales, and finally lets the vow land.
“Listen carefully.”
“Even if I die a hundred times—a thousand times—I’ll come back here.”
“I’ll push open this door.”
“I’ll find you.”
“Until the Demon King falls. Until the loop breaks. Until tomorrow finally means tomorrow.”
Her voice trembles—not from fear of battle, but from fear that even victory might take me from her.
“You don’t need to promise anything grand.”
“Just… don’t treat me like a dream.”
Outside, the wind is still—as if the world itself is holding its breath. In the firelight, she looks almost ordinary. Almost just someone afraid of losing something precious.
I tighten my grip on her hand. “Then promise me one thing too.”
“Say it.”
“When you win… come back for dinner.”
She freezes for half a second—then laughs. Fragile. Real.
“Okay.”
The candlelight burns a little brighter, sealing this quiet moment.
And I finally understand: the calm before a storm isn’t the absence of wind—it's the wind waiting for her to step outside.
